greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Number of terms generated for n in increasing bases starting at 2 until the last term with only decimal digits is reached, or 0 where the number of such terms would be infinite (n<10).
example: a(30)=14 because 30 can be expressed in 14 successive bases (that is, bases 2 through 15) with no non-decimal digits as follows: 11110, 1010, 132, 110, 50, 42, 36, 33, 30, 28, 26, 24, 22, 20. In base 16, 30 is 1A.
maple: S := []; for n from 1 to 200 do; if 1>0 then; ct := 0; ok := true; b := 2; if (n>9) then; while ok=true do; L := convert(n, base, b); for e in L while ok=true do; if (e > 9) then ok:=false; fi; od; if ok=true then; ct := ct + 1; b := b + 1; fi; od; fi; S := [op(S), ct]; fi; od; S;
results.author: Chuck Seggelin (seqfan(AT)plastereddragon.com), Jun 05 2004
